topic.title: Evaluation Stage

body.p: In this stage the filter results are walked through sequentially with order dependent on PASS/FAIL result. It starts with the first filter set with default action as 'drop'
If ith filter set is considered, depending on Pass/Fail result of it we have two cases

li.p: Case A: It passes. In this case final action at the end of this filter set is derived by current action set overriding or merging with previously accumulated actions depending on ‘continuation operator’. The next filter set is chosen depending on the ‘next_filter_offset’

Case B: It fails. In this case the actions accumulated from previous filter sets, if any, remains and the next filter set is the immediate filter set after the current set. At each filter set walk through, match indications are accumulated and events are thrown as indicated above at the end. If this is the last filter set then it exists.
There are three defect events (dEXM, dUPM, dGEM) and one eCSF event.
dEXM can be raised when there is a EXI mismatch
dUPM can be raised when there is a PTI/UPI mismatch
dGEM can be raised when there is a generic filter mismatch
eCSF can be raised for CSF event concluded by filter programming
Internally four defect flags are maintained. dUPM is split into dPTIM and dUPIM for PTI and UPI correspondingly.

dEXM, dPTIM, dUPIM: At the start of the evaluation phase, before any filter set is looked at, all these defect events are initialized to value '1'. As we start evaluation of filter sets, if the filter set passes corresponding match indicators ('USE_EXI_SET', 'USE_PTI_SET', 'USE_UPI_SET') are applied to these defect events initialized at start. If the filter set passes and any 'USE_*' of this filter set is configured as '1' then the corresponding defect initialized at the start of the evaluation phase is disabled (i.e. made '0')

dGEM : At the start of the evaluation phase, before any filter set is looked at, this defect event is initialized to value '0'. As we start evaluation of filter sets, if a filter set is configured with 'select_generic'='1' and 'USE_UPI_SET' configuration bit is set then the generic defect is raised if this filter mismatches or defect is cleared if this filter matches. On the other side if the 'select_generic' = '0' or 'USE_UPI_SET' = '0' then current value is retained for this defect flag.
At the end of evaluation, dPTIM and dUPIM are or-ed to give common event dUPM.

eCSF: At the start of the evaluation phase , before any filter set is looked at, this event is initialized to value '0'. As we start evaluation of filter sets, if the filter set passes corresponding match indicator is applied to this event initialized at start. If the filter set passes and this configured value in this filter set is programmed as '1' then the eCSF event is asserted (i:e made '1')

note.p: Mismatches in any given filter set is not always bad, such conditions can be used to maneuver the step by step process of filtering the received frame. Though in this case the mismatch indicators need to be used in a certain way.

body.p: Some examples to illustrate above note :

li.p: If a generic filter is used to split the matching process in two branches, then there is no need to set the generic mismatch event in this case and the USE_PTI_SET should be set to '0' so that this event is never generated.

Another case can be: If a UPI is to be matched for 0x13 or 0x14 then the first filter is expected to fail for some frames. So in this case the first filter checking should have offset jumping ahead of second filter ( such that when it passes we do not again check for 0x14). If the first filter set fails then we check for UPI = 0x14 in second filter and have offset to jump to same location as before. Here both filter should have USE_UPI_SET = '1' so that if any one of them passes we disable the UPI mismatch event.

body.p: Setting a mismatch event but still forwarding frame to egress interface is considered as invalid configuration (except for debug purpose).

Filter configuration is deemed to be invalid when there is no destination decided by filtering process and no defect events are recorded. If such condition is seen, it is expected to update the filter configurations to avoid this and instead throw appropriate defect events if no destination is decided.

In case of dEXM the type header fields are captured in an EXI mismatch status register which is common for all channels. There is additional provision to capture type header for dEXM event on a specific channel.

In case of dUPM, the type header fields are captured in a PTI/UPI mismatch status register which is common for all channels. There is additional provision to capture type header for these events on a specific channel.
